story:
UPDATE:  Thanks to everyone that contributed!  We didn't make our goal, but we gathered enough for some key parts.  We are going to updating everyone on our effort through our Facebook page: http://www.facebook.com/pages/Breast-Cancer-Data-Glove/399746566716836

 

The device is a glove that contains advanced sensors to electronically ‘feel’ for tumors during a routine breast exam. In addition to the clinician’s judgment, we hope the glove can generate data on suspicious lesions that require follow up.

We know getting a new cancer diagnostic tool is approved is going to be tough, so we're going to tackle these two problems first:


1) Global Health/ Telemedicine: in many places there is no healthcare available.  We believe minimally skilled workers can perform these exams and then email the data to experts for analysis.

2) A Training Tool for Medical Students: this device produces empirical data that can visualize different types of tumors during a CBE, thus improving training.

Where does the money go?
Your funds will go directly to paying for parts. Unlike other funding sources, no funds will go towards labor or overhead. 

  • ARFI ultrasound elements and electronics: $2k
  • Data acquisition device - $1.5k
  • Sensor board - $1k
  • Breast cancer phantom: $1k
  • Inertial measurement unit - $500
  • Glove and other sensor parts - $500
  • Soldering equipment and misc parts - $500

Why are you on IndieGoGo and not applying to Komen or NIH?
These types of grants are typically set aside for projects already showing promise or data.  IndieGoGo will help us generate pilot data, which we can use for these grants.

Potential discoveries:
Our goal is to create a glove that complements the clinical breast exam (CBE).  This device will record its own unique data as well as data from the clinician’s fingertip to provide an objective record of the exam.  This study will allow us to generate pilot data to apply for larger grants from institutes like the National Cancer Institute.

  1. We will fabricate prototype of CBE augmentation glove which generates force and ultrasound data (3 finger tips) as well as joint angle (all finger joints).  This in turn, will be used to generate: 1) Tissue compliance data and 2) Normalized Δt signals from ARFI ultrasound.  Data will be calibrated against known samples.
  2. We will use the compliance and ARFI normalized Δt signals to generate 2-axis time series test data to discriminate between control and "diseased" breast phantoms during mock CBE.
  3. We will use an artificial neural network to generate "tissue score" to discriminate breast tissue properties.  A continuum of tissue score and confidence level versus disease phantom properties will be presented and assessment made for the inexpensive non-radiological imaging of breast tissue, telemedicine and training tool potential for conducting CBEs.

Who are you guys?
A roboticist with a PhD in biomedical engineering from USC, an ultrasound scientist from USC and a breast cancer physician.

 

We’ve included more detailed information below:

Statement of the Problem:
The device allows the standardization of Clinical Breast Exams (CBEs) through generation of objective tactile and ultrasound data.  Malignant masses generally are hard, immobile, and fixed to surrounding skin and soft tissue, with poorly defined or irregular margins.  Benign masses generally cause no skin change and are smooth, soft to firm, and mobile, with well-defined margins (Barton,et al., 1999).  These features can be discriminated by sensing modalities that detect difference in tissue stiffness: e.g. force sensors and ultrasound.  This represents an advance in increased screening and gathering of objective data for populations that are transient amongst clinicians such as military personnel.   
Mammographic screening is also predicated on comparative analysis between mammograms.  This technology allows those same comparisons to occur.

Statement of How this Problem or Situation is Being Addressed:
We present a case for a Clinical Breast Exam Augmentation Glove: a device worn over a clinician’s hand that records finger position, joint angle, force and ultrasound measurements during a CBE to provide empirical data from CBE to CBE for patients.  This device represents possibilities in inexpensive non-radiological imaging of breast tissue, telemedicine in the military and training tool potential for conducting CBEs.
It is known that there is difference in the stiffness between cancerous and benign tissues.  The difference in stiffness also increases with the amount of strain in the tissues; thus relative stiffness as indicated by a tactile imaging device (such as the glove) rolling over tissue with ultrasound can aid in the discrimination of tumors.   


Other Ways You Can Help:
I cannot donate, is there another way to help?

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.  Visit our Facebook page: http://www.facebook.com/pages/Breast-Cancer-Data-Glove/399746566716836
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Our goal is to deliver this device to those in need; we want to buck the system: we plan to sell this equipment for cost-of-goods-sold…no profit. We want to get it out to as many in need as possible.  Why?  Imagine a world where new devices and discoveries are made with such a philosophy; imagine how many new things would be made available to all and not demarcated by the “haves and have-nots.”

Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:

ADD, ADHD, Bi-polar, different, avatars or simply Indigo?

 Indigo frequency. It is not a problem, it is a gift!

 (Indigo children) The term used for kid's who possess special abilities, because of extra active DNA strands, and more vibrational energy in their brains pineal gland (3rd eye).This makes them hyper sensitive to all frequencies of surrounding Aura's.They are very emotional, often energetic and highly intelligent, and will be the next great thinker's, healer's, inventor's, and artist's capable of applying more balance within our world. Sometimes western doctor's may term these kids with ADD, ADHD, manic, bi-polar, or autistic and place them on expensive medication, which will only numb their special qualities and abilities. Instead their  energy must be channeled and positively developed through meditation, proper diet and physical activity. ( These Kid's will be the one's to fix our current global down falls, but they must be encouraged, and directed positively.)

Indigo children/Enlightened youth program: ( The children are the future, but they must be shown how to lead and how to fix our current global issues) Through our program you learn to identify issues, find solutions and correct them with a special martial arts system, which develops mind, body & spirit balance. Our organization teaches and believes in health through vegan eating, meditation & fitness. We promote education of green living, renewable energy, energy sustainability and overall balance.

 

Serenitea;  delicious all natural Herbal Green tea blend to help open up Chakras, meridians and develop Indigo's ( w/green tea cinnamon, gogi berry, mint leaves, echanacia, and many other high antioxidant herbs.)

Open your Dormant DNA strands while experiencing Serenity.

 First we must find balance within ourselves, only then are we capable of applying balance within our world.

The truth about energy, Indigo's, star people, 2012 & the new era.

             

              High energy Solar flares- Magnetic Pole shift-raised electromagnetic field aura and energy around intuned beings
Everything is made up of energy and energy never dies, it simply changes form. Our greatest source of energy in the solar system is the sun, which has the frequency and ability to not only create all things, but also destroy all things. Think about it; if the sun were to burn out today all things would die. Humans, plants, animals, and bacteria, even the planets would fall out of orbit. The earth is a rippled past energy or fossil fuel of the sun and provides us with food, shelter, environment etc. This means the sun and earth are our two most important energy sources.The sun gives us a natural electric energy and the earth gives us magnetic energy. When you combine this energy you get electromagnetic energy which permeates all things. This energy is also known as chi, prana, breath of life and ether. story:
Care for Dylan

My name is Whitney Vittor, mother to three young girls. My husband and I are both small business owners who make enough to pay our bills but not much more.

Three years ago Danielle Crenshaw asked me to be Godmother to her infant son, Dylan Powell Crenshaw who was born on April 23, 2010. I was honored to be asked knowing how important this little guy is to his loving mother.

Dylan had a rough start. Before he was born he was diagnosed with hydrocephalus. After he was born he spent 8 days in NICU. At 6 months old he had a shunt placed to drain the fluid off of his brain and into his abdomen.

Since then he has been diagnosed with Hydrocephalus, Eosinophilic Esophagitis, GERD, Cerebral Palsy, Restrictive Lung Disease, Myositis, Hydronephrosis, Nephrolithiasis, 2 forms of Muscular Dystrophy- Walker Warburg (also known as muscle, eye, brain disease), and Bethlem myopathy, and a heart murmur.

Dylan cannot sit up on his own, hold his head up, walk, or talk but he can melt your heart with a single smile. He does not chew well and has to swallow 2-3 times to get a single bite of food down. He gets most of his nutrition from EleCare formula although he does eat some pureed type foods.

Dylan has been hospitalized more days than we can count. He is on growth hormone and steroids but remains in the 5th percentile for height and weight. He receives IVIg infusions every 2-3 weeks to try and keep his CK (muscle) level in a normal range. He has every specialist that there is and has travelled to Jackson, Mississippi and Iowa to see specialists. He still needs to go to Boston to see the specialists there.

Dylan requires special equipment and his needs grow as he grows. He uses a special bath chair, has a nebulizer for breathing treatments, uses special “Tumbleform” chairs to sit upright, has a wheelchair for mobility (although it doesn’t fit in his mother’s car, thankfully he can still fit in a stroller), and his newest addition will be a smart vest to help his lungs get rid of the extra mucous and keep them from failing.

Every day is a challenge and things most people take for granted Danielle and Dylan can’t do. She can’t take Dylan to the store to buy more than 3 or 4 things because he cannot sit in a buggy and there is only so much one can put on a stroller!

He doesn’t say “mommy” or “I love you” and he cannot walk to his mother’s room and crawl in her bed when he has a bad dream. He doesn’t give hugs or kisses or reach out to be picked up. But he is full of love and he is loved madly by anyone who meets him.

It isn’t the life Danielle imagined when she decided to have a baby but she wouldn’t change it for the world. Sure, she would give anything to take away the hurt he has and make his life easier but if asked, she’ll tell you that this life has given her strength that she never knew she had, compassion that she never thought possible, and a love that she will never have for anyone else.   

If we can join together as a community to share our blessings to help Dylan’s mom take care of his ever-growing needs and health care he will be assured to live as long as modern medicine and technology will allow.

To date donations have paid for his trip across country to undergo extensive tests to accurately diagnose him and more recently for devices to help him swim in a pool for the first time.

Dylan is grateful to have any help big or small. We hope you will make a contribution to his cause.  If a financial gift is not a possibility for you at this time, we ask that you please take advantage of the share tools available on this sight, telling friends and family about the opportunity to make a big difference in the life of an amazing little man.

Thank you.

story:
Short Summary

This is for Jordyn, my best friend.

On Columbus Day in 2011, Jordyn walked in to the New England Urgent Care Center. She had been sick for ten days with flu-like symptoms. She would later find out that she had a fever of 103 and an enlarged spleen. Jordyn didn’t return to her apartment for 18 days.

Jordyn would soon learn that she had Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML). At first, she was told "If you are going to get cancer, this is the cancer you want to get." That turned out to be not be the case for Jordyn. What they meant, was that most patients can manage CML with medication. However, in Jordyn's case, the pills do not prove effective. She has worked with a medical team for 18 months to find a combination that worked and to combat her cancer, but in May of this year, the decision was made to move forward with a bone marrow transplant. At this point, essentially, her only choice. 

Jordyn will be having her bone marrow transplant at Dana-Farber/Brigham and Women’s Cancer Center in Boston, Massachusetts. She will be admitted on July 31st and stay in Boston for approximately one month. During the first week she will undergo an intense pre-regimen of chemotherapy to eradicate most of the leukemia cells and suppress her existing immune system. On August 6th, Jordyn will receive her transplant. Jordyn is receiving her cells from a donor off of the national bone marrow registry who was chosen after her two brothers were found not to be matches. While the donor is not a perfect match, he is a single antigen mismatch that the medical team has deemed acceptable for transplant.

The road to recovery will not be an easy one. Jordyn is expected to be out of work for up to one year. During that time, she will be taking medication that will greatly suppress her immune system. Jordyn will be relegated to her apartment, with an intensley strict diet and hygeine regime and little contact with the outside world. As she prepares for her transplant, Jordyn has been spending as much quality time as possible with her family and close friends because in her words, "the future is uncertain and normalcy will be a long ways away."

This fund has been set up to help ease Jordyn's financial burden and help her as she goes down the road to get well. 

What We Need & What You Get

I am trying to raise at least $15,000 for Jordyn. This money will cover Jordyn's rent, utilities, car payment and insurance, health insurance premiums, egg cryopreservation and storage, co-pays, her mother's stay in Boston, travel and any other expenses Jordyn will have during the six months to a year that she cannot work.

Jordyn has been through so much and is so strong, and I want to make sure that she can concentrate on getting well. Please help me to help Jordyn find happiness and comfort as she begins this road to recovery.

To begin to offer each and every one of you my truest gratitude, I, along with a gathering of Jordyn's best pals will be creating homemade gifts of thanks. 

For your donations, we will send you a homemade friendship bracelet, a hand screened t-shirt or a signed photographic print.

But mostly, we will send you our love and admiration for being a friend to our friend and for helping a gal get back to good.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the word, and share this campaign with your friends.

Send Jordyn your good thoughts and prayers. You can follow her journey and keep in touch here: http://www.caringbridge.org/visit/jordynodonovan

If you can, please sign up for the bone marrow registry today. I cannot begin to express the love that we have for Jordyn's donor. A person that signed up for the registry and has decided to help someone that he has never met. It is truly an amazing gift. You can sign up here: https://www.deletebloodcancer.org/register/regi...

story:
Short Summary

A baby born in Ethiopia today is seven times more likely to die within the first four weeks of life than a baby born in the Western world.  Most infant deaths in Ethiopia could easily be prevented if Ethiopian hospital neonatal intensive care units had access to the essential supplies, equipment and training that are considered standard in hospitals and neonatal care units in the developed world. 

The Horn of Africa Neonatal Development Services, Inc. (HANDS) was established to address this need.  We assemble and coordinate volunteer medical teams who provide much-needed medical training to neonatal medical staff in Ethiopian hospitals.  We also coordinate and ship donations of essential medical supplies and equipment to Ethiopian hospitals.

History of HANDS 

In June 2010, Dr. Mesfin Woldesenbet visited Ethiopian hospitals that provided neonatal care.  He found that the quality of medical care provided to infants with medical problems was very suboptimal despite the efforts of hospital medical personnel and the Ethiopian Ministry of Health. 

During his visit, Dr. Woldesenbet observed newborns with various health problems being managed on a single bench with no warm blankets, no diapers, no monitoring devices to check their heart rates or breathing rates, and no intravenous pumps or oxygen supplies.

"My low moment was when I saw a 3-day-old newborn girl who had just had major abdominal surgery a few hours before I visited the unit.  She was gasping and fighting for her life.  She was not given any pain relief medication because none was available to give to her. As she struggled for her life, there was no ventilator support to aid her.  She had to share the only available oxygen source with other newborns on the same bench. It was heartbreaking to see what was happening and very difficult to walk away from.  I said to myself, 'It's time to be involved.  This is not fair. Something needs to be done.'

Our Mission and Goals

To improve neonatal care in Ethiopia, with the desired impact being the reduction of the high infant mortality rate of the country. How? By arranging year-round medical trips where medical volunteers from the United States share their medical knowledge and expertise with local health professionals. 

We also want to be involved in the educational process with Ethiopian schools that have neonatology training programs.

Facts and Statistics

A. The mortality rate for neonates (0-1 month olds) in Ethiopia is 29/1000 -- nearly seven times the neonatal mortality rate in the United States (4/1000)

B. The infant (0- 1 year olds) mortality rate in Ethiopia is 47/1000 live births, more than 13 times higher than the U.S. infant mortality rate of 6/1000 live births.

C.The still birth rate in East Africa is 27/1000 live births. 33% of the stillbirths occur during labor.

D. The three top causes of neonatal death in Ethiopia are infections, prematurity and birth asphyxia. In the U.S. the main causes of neonatal deaths are congenital or chromosomal anomalies and extreme prematurity.

E. The rate of deliveries attended by skilled personnel in Ethiopia is just 6% compared to 99% of newborn deliveries attended by skilled personnel in U.S. hospitals.


Progress / Accomplishments

Since 2010, our nonprofit organization has : 

  • Obtained numerous donations of essential medical supplies and equipment, and facilitated the shipment and delivery of these donations to Jimma University Hospital.  
  • Coordinated two volunteer medical teams of neonatal specialists consisting of a neonatologist, a registered nurse, and a registered respiratory therapist to travel to Ethiopia in April and June, 2013 to deliver supplies, equipment and medical training to medical personnel at Jimma University Hospital.

The Impact

Over the past year we have provided Jimma University Hospital with : 

1. Ten Oximeters, enabling the unit to go from monitoring capacity of 0 to 10 babies.

2. Multiple boxes of CPAP equipment to help with lung and breathing problems - a significant improvement to the unit.

3.   Essential medical supplies such as syringes, diapers, bandages and antibiotics.

4.   Improved emergency communication between Neonatal ICU and obstetrician by providing an alternative medium (Walkie Talkies) as telephone and internet services are not reliable.

5.   Training to the doctors and nurses on neonatal care.

6.  A forum where knowledge and best practices can be shared via our website.


What We Need 

  • We need to raise $50,000 to pay for the travel expenses (air fare, lodging and meals) for each 3-member team's two-week visit to Ethiopia during 2014.  Attaining this goal will enable us to fund five medical training visits during 2014.

  • All amounts raised through the Indiegogo campaign will be used to pay for our volunteer medical teams' travel  and other costs associated with transporting and delivering medical supplies and equipment to Ethiopia.

To Learn More About HANDS

www.handsforbabies.org 

For More Information on Ways You Can Help, Click Here

A Medical Volunteer Shares Her Experience

HANDS Activity Updates

HANDS Videos
story_txt:
Short Summary
A baby born in Ethiopia today is seven times more likely to die within the first four weeks of life than a baby born in the Western world.  Most infant deaths in Ethiopia could easily be prevented if Ethiopian hospital neonatal intensive care units had access to the essential supplies, equipment and training that are considered standard in hospitals and neonatal care units in the developed world. 
The Horn of Africa Neonatal Development Services, Inc. (HANDS) was established to address this need.  We assemble and coordinate volunteer medical teams who provide much-needed medical training to neonatal medical staff in Ethiopian hospitals.  We also coordinate and ship donations of essential medical supplies and equipment to Ethiopian hospitals.
History of HANDS 
In June 2010, Dr. Mesfin Woldesenbet visited Ethiopian hospitals that provided neonatal care.  He found that the quality of medical care provided to infants with medical problems was very suboptimal despite the efforts of hospital medical personnel and the Ethiopian Ministry of Health. 
During his visit, Dr. Woldesenbet observed newborns with various health problems being managed on a single bench with no warm blankets, no diapers, no monitoring devices to check their heart rates or breathing rates, and no intravenous pumps or oxygen supplies.
"My low moment was when I saw a 3-day-old newborn girl who had just had major abdominal surgery a few hours before I visited the unit.  She was gasping and fighting for her life.  She was not given any pain relief medication because none was available to give to her. As she struggled for her life, there was no ventilator support to aid her.  She had to share the only available oxygen source with other newborns on the same bench. It was heartbreaking to see what was happening and very difficult to walk away from.  I said to myself, 'It's time to be involved.  This is not fair. Something needs to be done.'
Our Mission and Goals

To improve neonatal care in Ethiopia, with the desired impact being the reduction of the high infant mortality rate of the country. How? By arranging year-round medical trips where medical volunteers from the United States share their medical knowledge and expertise with local health professionals. 
We also want to be involved in the educational process with Ethiopian schools that have neonatology training programs.
Facts and Statistics
A. The mortality rate for neonates (0-1 month olds) in Ethiopia is 29/1000 -- nearly seven times the neonatal mortality rate in the United States (4/1000)
B. The infant (0- 1 year olds) mortality rate in Ethiopia is 47/1000 live births, more than 13 times higher than the U.S. infant mortality rate of 6/1000 live births.C.The still birth rate in East Africa is 27/1000 live births. 33% of the stillbirths occur during labor.D. The three top causes of neonatal death in Ethiopia are infections, prematurity and birth asphyxia. In the U.S. the main causes of neonatal deaths are congenital or chromosomal anomalies and extreme prematurity.E. The rate of deliveries attended by skilled personnel in Ethiopia is just 6% compared to 99% of newborn deliveries attended by skilled personnel in U.S. hospitals.Progress / AccomplishmentsSince 2010, our nonprofit organization has : 

Obtained numerous donations of essential medical supplies and equipment, and facilitated the shipment and delivery of these donations to Jimma University Hospital.  


Coordinated two volunteer medical teams of neonatal specialists consisting of a neonatologist, a registered nurse, and a registered respiratory therapist to travel to Ethiopia in April and June, 2013 to deliver supplies, equipment and medical training to medical personnel at Jimma University Hospital.

The ImpactOver the past year we have provided Jimma University Hospital with : 1. Ten Oximeters, enabling the unit to go from monitoring capacity of 0 to 10 babies.2. Multiple boxes of CPAP equipment to help with lung and breathing problems - a significant improvement to the unit.
3.   Essential medical supplies such as syringes,
diapers, bandages and antibiotics.
4.   Improved emergency communication between Neonatal ICU and
obstetrician by providing an alternative medium (Walkie Talkies) as
telephone and internet services are not reliable.
5.   Training to the doctors and nurses on neonatal
care.6.  A forum
where knowledge and best practices can be shared via our website.What We Need We need to raise $50,000 to pay for the travel expenses (air fare, lodging and meals) for each 3-member team's two-week visit to Ethiopia during 2014.  Attaining this goal will enable us to fund five medical training visits during 2014.All amounts raised through the Indiegogo campaign will be used to pay for our volunteer medical teams' travel  and other costs associated with transporting and delivering medical supplies and equipment to Ethiopia.To Learn More About HANDSwww.handsforbabies.org For More Information on Ways You Can Help, Click HereA Medical Volunteer Shares Her ExperienceHANDS Activity UpdatesHANDS Videos

story:
Short Summary

We are Bill and Ellie Butler, founders of Solar Solutions Team. This is a nonprofit association of like minded organizations and individuals.  See www.solarsolutionsteam.jimdo.com/

 We have been supporting the work of those organizations that supply solar food cooking and drying, solar pasteurizing and solar battery charging for many years.  

United Nations Report: Polluted drinking water claim more lives than all forms of violence, including war.  “At least 1.8 million children die annually as a result of contaminated water”.

"The measure of a civilization is how it treats it's weakest members".  Mahatma Ghandi

Our current project is a Solar Water Pasteurizer that can save hundreds of thousands of lives.  It is based on the work of Dr. Bob Metcalf of the University of California, Sacramento.  See http://splashurl.com/mt8ma7a/  The solar pasteurizer is comprised of a solar hot water panel, a thermostatic control valve and a  pasteurized water reservoir.  The sun heats water in the panel but it is not released into the reservoir until it has  been above the pasteurizing temperature for 10 minutes.  The unique design allows the use of inexpensive materials.  This equipment can be assembled in a poor country.  This reduces freight charges and providesd employment.

The standard solution to clean water is drilling deep wells.  They are expensive, require heavy equipment and take time.  Thus, they are not practical in all situations including disaster zones.  It is reported that many wells are now out of operation because of maintenance failure.

We have energy, enthusiasm, ideas and technical skills. We lack the funds to move this project along at the pace we would like.

What We Need 

We seek $5,000 in order to accomplish the following:

1.  $2500 of the total will be in cash to purchase news tools and materials.
2.  $2500 will be contributed in the form of volunteer labor.
3.  Fine tune the design of the product.
4.  Purchase a special tool to increase quality and reduce fabrication time.
5.  Develop more detailed training materials to ease the assembly, use and effectiveness of the product.
6. We will contribute 60% of our receipts to an international charity that is already established in poor countries and understands the clean water problem. It will test the pasteurizer in a poor country and report the results.  Next, we will build a program to supply these solar pasteurizes in the quantities needed. 
7. There is a good possibility that these units could be assembled in the country where they are being used.  This will provide employment as well as clean water.

Results Expected

This equipment will save hundreds of thousands of lives.  

Project Status

We have 6 units in the field now and are building 2 more.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Help us get the word out about this valuable project. Tell others

  • Use the share tools on this site to include others.

  • Volunteer time to help

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
My Name is Charlie, I live in a small village called Hythe in Hampshire. 

I recently found out that my Grandparents applied for a grant through Age Concern and were unfortunately declined to have their bathroom re-fitted to make life easier. 

My Nan has recently found out she needs an operation as she's developed osteoporosis in her knee. This causes the ligaments to deteriorate leaving only the bones, as you can imagine this makes movement very difficult and painful, so climbing in and out of a bath is no longer ideal. 

Raising money for them to have a new bathroom fitted would mean the world to me and my family. 

I will be doing a sponsored sky dive in the new year and would appreciate as much support from family and friends as possible! 

My aim is to raise £5,000 so they can have their bath removed and a new shower cubicle fitted to make getting in and out more suitable. The bathroom will be re-done completely and any funds left over will go to the Osteoporosis Charity. 

Thank you  for all your donations and support. 

Charlie

This causes the ligaments to deteriorate leaving only the bones, as you can imagine this makes movement very difficult and painful, so climbing in and out of a bath is no longer ideal. Raising money for them to have a new bathroom fitted would mean the world to me and my family. I will be doing a sponsored sky dive in the new year and would appreciate as much support from family and friends as possible! My aim is to raise £5,000 so they can have their bath removed and a new shower cubicle fitted to make getting in and out more suitable. story:
My name is Lynne Miller and I am a certified yoga and meditation teacher who has been teaching full time for 15 years.  I work with a lot of elderly students and people who have chronic health issues.  Recently I injured my back and I had 3 treatments on the Rickway Amethyst Biomat and they helped me so much!  I feel called to purchase a BioMat, a massage table and a few more healing classes so that I can offer this Holistic Healing to others.  You don't make much as a full time yoga teacher, but I find my path so rewarding in many other ways.  All money  collected will go to the purchase of the Biomat, massage table and healing classes.  The world needs more healing.....



                                             Lynne Miller, CYT ~ Bio 2014


   
  Lynne received her 200 hour certification from Atma Yoga in 2000.  Atma Yoga is a Kripalu based yoga which is founded in core strength and safety of the body.  After working in the medical field for 16 years, as a Medical Assistant and Office Manager in pediatric and family medicine, she honors the way that yoga addresses the mind, body connection.  Lynne completed a 5 day Vinyasa Flow Teacher’s Intensive with Shiva Rea.  She enjoys putting vinyasas or yoga flows together to help create releases.  She also works with creative visualization during relaxation, which led her to a Yoga Nidra training at Kripalu Yoga Center in July 2004. This now allows her to share her love of the deep relaxation of Yoga Nidra. This guided deep relaxation is especially helpful for those with chronic physical or emotional pain.
  Lynne has been teaching yoga full time for 15 years now.  She was a core teacher at Westfield Yoga Studio for 4 years, a core teacher at Heartsong Yoga in East Longmeadow, MA for 3 years and in 2006 opened Simply Yoga Studio in East Windsor, CT.  For 11 years now, she has been teaching 6 weekly classes at the Enfield Senior Center and has recently developed a new class taught there called Simply Stretch and Strengthen and Balance which also works with memory, balance, and coordination. She teaches a Yoga class at Asnuntuck Community College for credit.  Lynne spent two weeks of the summer of 2005 assisting her yoga teacher, Christopher Ken Baxter at the Omega Center in Rhinebeck, NY. In the spring of 2005, she had a piece published in the book, Yoga Meditations ~Timeless Mind-Body Practices.








Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

Phaidra Knight is a 2014 Winter Olympic hopeful for the U.S. Bobsledding Team. She is one of the most renowned rugby players in the world with credentials that include three appearances in the Rugby World Cup, 2-time All World Team honoree, and USA Rugby Player of the Decade.

The athletic recipe required to be a champion “brakeman” in the sport of bobsledding is similar explosive power, strength, quickness and agility she possesses which gained her stardom in rugby. 

Phaidra has dedicated over ten years to professional rugby, traveling all over the globe. She now has the opportunity to achieve the ultimate athletic honor of becoming an Olympian. Translating her compassion and sports celebrity into philanthropy serving others, Phaidra aspires to launch a global nonprofit that will speak to the needs of youth education, fitness and health/wellness. 

What We Need & What You Get

Phaidra needs your support and donations to help fund her training. She travels to Lake Placid and Park City to train with U.S. Bobsled Team members. In order to spend the necessary time and costly expense to train with the best coaches and trainers, Phaidra will need to forfeit her job and commit herself 100%. She has set a training budget of 50K, but every contribution will be valuably utilized.

To complete this journey tangibly, Phaidra desires to be in the position to invite her supporters to join her in Sochi, Russia in 2014. For those who cannot be present, Phaidra has constructed memorable signature gifts related to her sport celebrity including "toRUSSIAwithLOVE” campaign t-shirts, bobsled race suits, bobsled helmet, U.S. Rugby jerseys and rugby balls) to mention a few. She also will be acknowledging the friends and organizations that support her on the various media outlets she will be appearing.

In the event that Phaidra cannot participate on the Olympic Team, remaining funds will be donated to the Women’s Sports Foundation. 

The Impact

This journey is really about helping Phaidra help others--to help put her in a position to inspire and positively influence kids. Phaidra is rallying positive individuals to support and take this journey with her which will be kindly reciprocated through her commitment to abolishing childhood obesity and related health-wellness issues. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are not in a position to contribute monetarily, Phaidra would appreciate you sharing her story and getting the word out through social media and Indiegogo share tools.

Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/phaidra.knight

Twitter: http://twitter.com/phaidraknight / #toRUSSIAwithLOVE

story:
On April 18, 2014, Solo violinist, Martin De Deugd, of Amsterdam has suffered and debilitating worst possible accident that can happen to a fine violinist!

His bowing arm was crushed! ( please see ' Gallery' for a picture) 

He was biking through the streets of Amsterdam, just getting back from a gig, he was traveling at great speed down a hill, then for some reason his front wheel of the bike jammed and locked dead; with gravity taking over, and the physics of motion, he was thrown head over heels over the bike steering column, and slammed into the pavement. Trying to protect his head from hitting the pavement, in that spit second, his used his right arm to shield it, this impact crushed his right elbow! His bowing arm! He has undergone one surgery so far, with more to come.

The most devastating and concerning issue now, with his recovery, will he ever be able to play his violin again?

Being a violin soloist in Holland, his only source income comes from his performances. With the new Dutch Government and its laws, Martin will receive very little insurance benefits as a freelance musician.  If he is not able to perform he has a poverty level of income, which will result in a devastating financial disaster.

Martin de Deugd has performed as a soloist throughout Europe and world over the past 20 years. He has over 100 cd recordings as a soloist. Has performed in countless concert halls through-out Europe, including the Concertgebouw Amsterdam , De Doelen in Rotterdam and The Queen Elizabeth Hall in Antwerp.  

Internationally, Martin de Deugd played concerts in Tokyo and Nagoya and played recitals with the Canadian concert pianist Patricia Parr in Toronto. Martin de Deugd has been a soloist in the Musical  “Dietrich " alongside Jasperina de Jong in the role of Marlene Dietrich . 

He was in several musicals and shows concertmaster including Titanic , Rembrandt and the TV show " Una Voce Particulare . He has contributed to numerous CD and TV recordings of religious repertoire ( Netherlands Sing ) and is thus a soloist at concerts of many church choirs found in the Netherlands , but also a soloist at Notre Dame in Paris, the Berliner Dom and the Copenhagen Cathedral .

Please help with a donation to Martin, so that he can concentrate on his long road of recovery and many, many hours of physiotherapy. And let him worry less about where the next Euro is going to come from to be able to pay his rent and afford the necessities of life!

About Wendy Limbertie, Martin de Deugd’s fundraising campaign manager and cheerleader!

From 1983 to 2000, Wendy Limbertie was principal horn of the Hoofstad Operette (Amsterdam Opera Company) and there is where Martin and Wendy met. Martin was Concertmaster of the HO orchestra and became instant friends with Wendy; they have remained close friends for over 30 years now. They have performed countless concerts together throughout Holland, Belgium, Germany and Switzerland, both orchestral and in chamber music. In 2001 Wendy moved back to her homeland of Canada, and continued her music career there. Martin and Wendy have always kept in touch even though there may be 6000 km apart. Social media has made this world a very small and accessible place!

About Wendy Limbertie, Martin de Deugd’s fundraising campaign manager and cheerleader!From 1983 to 2000, Wendy Limbertie was principal horn of the Hoofstad Operette (Amsterdam Opera Company) and there is where Martin and Wendy met. Martin was Concertmaster of the HO orchestra and became instant friends with Wendy; they have remained close friends for over 30 years now. They have performed countless concerts together throughout Holland, Belgium, Germany and Switzerland, both orchestral and in chamber music. In 2001 Wendy moved back to her homeland of Canada, and continued her music career there. Martin and Wendy have always kept in touch even though there may be 6000 km apart. Social media has made this world a very small and accessible place!

story:
Disabled Aldona asks for help - money for very expensive medicaments.

I was born without hands and one leg. I've been suffering from Chronic Pancreatitis since I was 16,at the end of last year I was diagnosed with Crohn's disease. 

My name is Aldona Plewinska, I'm from Katowice in Poland. I was born without hands and a right leg. So far no one knows why I was born with a disability, despite the fact that on the ultrasound everything was all right. Doctors from the beginning gave me little chance to survive, because I also had too small heart which at any time could stop working. Now I'm 21 years old and I'm on the first year of the extramural studies in Journalism and Social Communication. Unfortunately because of the health reasons it is very hard for me to be at the university 12 hours a day every weekend. I have been suffering from Chronic Pancreatitis since I was 16, and at the end of last year I was diagnosed with Crohn's disease. What is it? It's a type of inflammatory bowel disease of unknown etiology, included in the group of non-specific inflammatory bowel diseases. It may affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract but usually locates in the final part of the small intestine. Unfortunately, there is no medicine that would entirely cure the disease but doctors from Luxemburg, who treated me, recommended the HUMIRA (Adalimumab in the international language). HUMIRA is an immunosuppressant, a recombinant human monoclonal antibody. This medicine was first used in 2002 on patients with moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis, then it has begun to be used to treat other rheumatic diseases. It was not until the 2006 that the European Crohn's and Colitis Organisation informed, that HUMIRA can also be used to treat adults with Crohn's disease. I take the medicine in form of injections (one dose is 40 mg of solution) regularly every two weeks. The medicine is quite new and because of that a single dose, one injection 40mg of Adalimumab costs around 3000zł in Poland, in Luxembourg 500Euros. So far Hand an Hand foundation from Luxemburg has been funding the HUMIRA for me, I was their ward until I turned 18. Since that time I can no longer be the part of the foundation but they still help me financially. The Hand an Hand foundation has many dependents, mostly children from Brazil. They have been helping them for many years, therefore I would like to relive them from giving 1000 Euros each month on HUMIRA and that is why I'm asking you for help.

The aim of this campaign is 2000Euros, but any amount is very valuable for me.

In 2009 I started to model and take part in many projects. Since then I have had many photo sessions and there have been several television documentaries about me.
I'm not doing this for money, just because it has been my dream since childhood to have a professional photo session. Unfortunately, is spite of so many photo shoots and other projects in which I participated I'm still lacking of money for medicines.
It is impossible to make money on modelling, unfortunately no one wants to pay wages for the sessions and usually I do it for free.
People with disabilities have a very hard life in Poland, the state pays pittance.
With my attitude to life I would like to show all disable people that it is worth to fulfill your dreams and passions. Also I would like other people to realize that we disable people are just as valuable as others and we also want to live, dream and develop ourselves.

You can find all of my photoes and videos on my Facebook page- http://www.facebook.com/pages/Aldonka/284339774950246?ref=hl

Once again I would like to ask for your help and thank you in advance.

Kind regards
Aldonka

story:
Short Summary

Hi, my name is allan martins. I'm a professor at Federal University of Rio Grande do Norte here in Brazil. Since I graduated (1999-2000) I was fascinated by image processing the how it could be used to improve life. I got my masters with a project of cancer cell counting. Back there I implemented the software in the PC and wasn't practical to distribute it.
Now with the help of portable devices technology it became very easy to distribute softwares as apps.

So, my goal is to code an app that will help pathologists to diagnose cancer by using immunohistochemical images. Today, practically all the biopsies made uses some kind of image analysis. Unfortunately, the analysis requires the pathologist to count the hundreds and even thousands of cells in the image to get a precise result.
By using a tool that can be portable and very easy to use, the diagnostics can become more precise and agile, helping to fight cancer and improve the general human health.

What We Need & What You Get

The app is already in development, but we need your help to finish it. As the members have to work on many things in their daily life, we need some kind of funding to focus our work in the implementation of the app.
In summary, we need the money mostly to pay work/hour of the developers. Also we have to maintain the server and the on-line service that the app uses.

As the app is already in development, so, any fund we get is a contribution! We have several perks that you can contribute on!
The payback will be in exams licenses in the app (packages that allows you to perform from 5 to unlimited number of exams).

The Impact

Today, practically all the biopsies made uses some kind of image analysis. Unfortunately, the analysis requires the pathologist to count the hundreds and even thousands of cells in the image to get a precise result.
By using a tool that can be portable and very easy to use, the diagnostics can become more precise and agile, helping to fight cancer and improve the general human health.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute monetarily, or you already funding other projects, you can still help! Please share out project with friends in facebook, google+, twitter, etc… You will be helping us to give a small but significant step towards the cancer fight in the world!

story:
Mom wants your help to get a creamery started at Misty Brook Farm. She and her friends have plenty of milk they would like to donate to the cause. We have the opportunity to purchase a whole small-scale creamery from Olde Oak Farm. The creamery is in an Amish built structure on skids for easy relocation. It is fully equipped with a cheese vat, cheese press, cheese cave, as well as all of the accessories and tools needed to produce a wonderful array of soft and hard cheeses. This has all been offered to Misty Brook for only $40,000! (It would cost close to $80,000 to build.)

Mom has already got John signed on as her passionate cheese maker. Cinnamon, Floppy, and all their friends can’t wait for whey. It’s like ice cream for pigs!


History

Misty Brook Farm started in 2005 as a small raw milk dairy in Central Mass. The cows are certified organic and 100% grass-fed. As the farm grew, pigs, chickens, vegetables, and grains were added. In 2013, after a long search, the farm family found a permanent home in Albion, ME. In the past, batches of cheese have been made using creameries owned by fellow farmers. Now that Misty Brook has put down roots, it is time for a Misty Brook Creamery!


Farm Family

Mom’s farm team is made up of four couples. Brendan and Katia make hay for the cows, grow grains, oversee general operations, and keep the office in check. Their sons, Alister and Johnny help out everywhere, especially when it involves getting dirty. Nell and Justin, with help from the horses, grow the fantastic array of vegetables and keep things going at the Somerville Farmers' Market. John and Megan keep things in order with the dairy processing, grain processing, and delivery route. Josh and Elexis, who just joined the team, have taken on the jobs of keeping the pigs and chickens well fed, as well as adding flowers and herbs to the mix. With all this great help, imagine all the wild and wonderful cheeses that could come out of this creamery!

Help Mom make this happen for the whole farm and all of our farm customer friends.

Bring back the gouda, cheddar, blue, ... and something new!

story: Steve Wilson was diagnosed with Esophageal Cancer on June 18, 2011. The doctors told him that this was the cancer that would kill him. This diagnose fell on deaf ears for his family, we are very positive and say he would beat this cancer. We went for a second opinion at UT Southwestern in Dallas TX and the cancer doctor was very positive but did add that depending on the stage of the cancer it could kill him. We began the journey of treatment. Steve received 5 and 1/2 weeks of radiation and two weeks of chemo. During this treatment journey we made several visits to the ER due to the effects of the radiation and chemo on his body and 3 hospital stays for extreme dehydration and pneumonia. Each time we went to the ER and he was admitted there was a $500 co-pay, along with a $100 co-pay for just going to the ER, a $25 co-pay for seeing the doctor and medication to treat the side effects some of which were not covered by insurance. Treatment has completed and we are scheduled for another esophageal scope in January 2012. Depending on the diagnoses he will undergo surgery to remove his esophagus or continue chemo. His wife Kathy, was laid off in August of 2011 and for three months was denied unemployment, she appealed that decision and won that appeal. With 4 months of bills, doctorsâ€™ bills and prescription we are now tapped out. Any additional funds raised after bills are paid will go to the American Cancer Society in the names of anyone that contributed.

story:
Hi my name is Christina Smith and I would say that I have been a serious runner for about three years now. About a year ago I came up with a goal to run my first marathon when I turn 30. Even though I may not qualify for the Boston Marathon by then it's still a goal to run one. I'm turning 29 soon. I was thinking of doing a half marathon before running the big one. I tried to sign up last year for the half marathon but didn't make it in. 

My training continued. Spring had ended and I hear some bad news from a close friend. She was diagnosed with breast cancer. I've never personally known anybody with cancer. I didn't quite understand what it was she was about to go through. She is only 32. She had a lot of support from friends and family, but it's still a physical, mental, and emotional journey she has to make alone. Dana farber was there to provide financial and emotional support. So when I saw that they had a Boston half marathon team I jumped at the chance to do my part.

Dana Farber asks runners for a $500 commitment. Funds will go towards cancer research and providing emotional and financial support those diagnosed with cancer. What they are doing is amazing. They are making a frightening ordeal manageable and less stressful. Their ultimate goal is to rid the world of cancer. If I do not reach my goal every penny still goes to Dana Farber and I will try to raise funds through other means. If I go over my goal I would like to donate most to Dana Farber and use very little for race day supplies.

I can't imagine what she went through. It seemed painful, frightening, uncomfortable and agonizing even at times. She's the strongest person I know. She was able to even walk the Susan Komen 3 Day not even a month after a major medical operation. She is determined and empowered! And Dana Farber helped give her a healthy chance at life. This is my way and your way of giving somebody else that chance. Our chance to help an organization that empowers and gives hope where there would otherwise be no hope. 

If this story hits close to home or if you know of somebody who may like to donate please pass this story on. Dana Farber is also always looking for volunteers as well. If you would like to learn more please visit www.dana-farber.org . On October 7th I'm no longer just running for myself. I'm running for those with cancer, I'm running for my friend, I'm running for Dana Farber, and I'm running for all of you who are kind enough to show your support.

story:
My sister Megan and I are trying to raise/collect as much donations as possible for my dads funeral after he passes away. The doctor said he has weeks to live but by the way he looks it might not be that long. Around Thanksgiving i tried to contact my dad so i can wish him a Happy Thanksgiving. I never got a call back figuring he must have been busy at work because he always has his phone turned off the days he works. Well not too long after i get a call from my sister telling me our dad quit his job do to being sick and hasn't contacted anyone or asked for help. My sister found this out from his job who sent health inspectors to his house. Megan told me dad answered the door and the health inspector found he was "out of it" and very thin. As soon as Megan could she took a trip up to dad's and saw for herself how bad off he was doing. So a few days later she moved him in with her, her new baby and husband. The month he was living with my sister he became more ill and wasn't eating. My dad was just diagnosed with diabetes a few months earlier but there is no way that was the reason for his weight loss. Monday Jan. 9Th 2012 i get a call from Megan, "dad is in the hospital....he fell in the bathroom and busted his lip open and had to have stitches." She also told me he had jaundice which she didn't realize he has because dad was always in the dark and didn't want to be bothered. Later that day i get another call, this time she was crying. She went on to tell me she got a call from the doctor and dad has been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer and he only has weeks to live. I didn't know what to think, just that i had to find a way to see my dad before he passes away. I am currently living in Daytona Beach FL where i have been living for the past year and a half. All my family lives in California so coming up with the finances to pay for a plane ticket was nearly impossible. I called any family member i could to help me out with a ticket....nothing. Finally i talked to a cousin i just found out i had and she contacted my aunt i haven't seen since i was a baby. She gave me a call and said she could help me get a plane ticket, that she to was going to fly out from Hawaii to see her brother. The next day i get my ticket and pack for my trip. Do to financial reasons, I could only stay to visit my dad for a week.

The Impact

( My father will be so thankful for your donations and someday if you or your family needs help, I will be there with a helping hand. I am forever indebted to you. Thank you so much! )


What We Need & What You Get

(Having a baby to take care of and still working, Megan is dealing with a lot of pressure. That is another reason I went there to visit, so I could be there to support my sister. I am putting together this campaign so I can fly out to help my sister and take some of the pressure off her shoulders. The donations will get me a plane ticket back out to California to be there for my sister and the rest will go toward his funeral/memorial service. My sister and I are also setting out donation bucket to help out. If we don't reach out goal the amount collected will go strait toward his burial. No matter how much is collected i will always be grateful for the people who help out. If you donate i will personally write you a letter thanking you.)


Other Ways You Can Help

( I know in this economy its financially hard on some people so if you cannot donate that is alright. You can do something to help though...tell a friend or pass the word along. Maybe you could post my story on Facebook, Myspace or Twitter. I would appreciate all the help i can get. Thank you so much and God bless. :) )

story:
I'm Mike Beasley and I hate iOS 7. I have declared that I will never run it. Despite the fact that I have repeatedly stated that I have no plans to update, some people continue to bug me about updating, including one traitorous coworker who previously hated it as much as I did.

As a challege to these people, I created this campaign. If it gets funded, I'll update to iOS 7. And I'll donate all the money to charity.

Stretch Goals

If we reach the following amounts, I'll do some extra stuff on top of the donation:

$1,000 - I will not complain about iOS 7 on Twitter for a full week. The week will begin shortly after the stretch goal is met.

Update: This goal was met at 1PM on December 9th. The one week without iOS 7 complaints started immediately and will end at 1PM on December 16th.

$2,000 - I will write a post of my top ten favorite new things in iOS 7 on my personal blog. This will likely be a painful experience for me.

$6,000 - This is the price to sponsor a hand-dug well through charity: water. If we reach this goal, I'll finally give in to numerous Twitter followers' requests (which I have long rejected) and watch one (1) episode of My Little Pony. The episode will be selected by Steve Streza, as he is the most-qualified person I know to make that decision.

$10,000 - TBD - Seems like a long shot, but this is the price of a machine-drilled well. If we get here, I'll do something crazy (reasonably!). I don't know what yet. I'll figure something out.

Questions That Have Not Really Been Asked Frequently But Are Probably Running Through Someone's Mind

Why $500?

Because it's the minimum goal you're allowed to enter. I initially set it low expecting that it would never be reached anyway. When I decided not to keep the money, it was convenient to have a low goal since that would make it easier to actually reach, and thus easier to make the donation.

I still don't want to be on iOS 7 though, so this is a bittersweet goal.

What will you do with the money?

I initially planned to keep the money, but I have since decided to donate the proceeds to charity: water, an organization that builds wells in countries that do not have access to clean water.

100% of charity: water donations go directly toward building wells.

Everything above and beyond the goal amount will be donated, too. I'll invent some ridiculous stretch goals if we get close to $500.

Why did you decide to give the money to charity?

After making the first donation to this campaign, my coworker Michael Steeber noted the (intentional) absurdity of the campaign on Twitter:

1st world: I just donated $5 over the internet to try to convince a guy I’ve never met [in-person] to touch his finger to the screen on his $500 phone

He followed it up with this:

@MikeBeas @SebOrSam the more i think about this campaign the more ridiculous it seems. think about 3rd world countries etc

After thinking about that for a minute, I decided that keeping $500 to update my phone was a ridiculous idea (and was intended as such). I don't really need $500. Plenty of other people could benefit from that money, though.

Why did you pick charity: water?

I don't drink anything but bottled water. I love bottled water. It's so much cleaner than what comes out of the tap at my apartment. But some people can't run to Walmart and buy a 24-pack of Deer Park when they need it. Sometimes they have to drink whatever is available—if anything.

The water from my tap is techncially consumable, but the one time I drank it I nearly gagged. Millions of people don't even have water as clean as my tap water. That's not OK. Let's do something to fix that.

Why do you hate iOS 7?

Because it is ugly. I like much of the functionality they introduced, but the design is really bad.

Why should I want you to update to iOS 7?

Because you are one of those people who thinks iOS 7 is so great everyone should use it. Or maybe you hate skeuomorphism and want to see it eradicated. Or perhaps you just want to see my unfiltered thoughts about it on Twitter. I honestly have no idea why you would want this. I know I don't.

I don't know who you are.

That's not a question.

Who are you?

That's better. I'm Mike. Hi.

Note: The sleep button on my phone is starting to fail. In the event that this campaign is funded and I get a replacement phone from AppleCare, and that replacement phone is running iOS 6, I will sadly update that phone to iOS 7 in keeping with the promises made here. And yes, either way the money will go to charity: water. Duh.
story_txt:
I'm Mike Beasley and I hate iOS 7. I have declared that I will never run it. Despite the fact that I have repeatedly stated that I have no plans to update, some people continue to bug me about updating, including one traitorous coworker who previously hated it as much as I did.As a challege to these people, I created this campaign. If it gets funded, I'll update to iOS 7. And I'll donate all the money to charity.Stretch GoalsIf we reach the following amounts, I'll do some extra stuff on top of the donation:$1,000 - I will not complain about iOS 7 on Twitter for a full week. The week will begin shortly after the stretch goal is met.Update: This goal was met at 1PM on December 9th. The one week without iOS 7 complaints started immediately and will end at 1PM on December 16th.$2,000 - I will write a post of my top ten favorite new things in iOS 7 on my personal blog. This will likely be a painful experience for me.$6,000 - This is the price to sponsor a hand-dug well through charity: water. If we reach this goal, I'll finally give in to numerous Twitter followers' requests (which I have long rejected) and watch one (1) episode of My Little Pony. The episode will be selected by Steve Streza, as he is the most-qualified person I know to make that decision.$10,000 - TBD - Seems like a long shot, but this is the price of a machine-drilled well. If we get here, I'll do something crazy (reasonably!). I don't know what yet. I'll figure something out.Questions That Have Not Really Been Asked Frequently But Are Probably Running Through Someone's MindWhy $500?Because it's the minimum goal you're allowed to enter. I initially set it low expecting that it would never be reached anyway. When I decided not to keep the money, it was convenient to have a low goal since that would make it easier to actually reach, and thus easier to make the donation.I still don't want to be on iOS 7 though, so this is a bittersweet goal.What will you do with the money?I initially planned to keep the money, but I have since decided to donate the proceeds to charity: water, an organization that builds wells in countries that do not have access to clean water.100% of charity: water donations go directly toward building wells.Everything above and beyond the goal amount will be donated, too. story:
Supporting Michelle and her daughters

Michelle is one of my closest friends going back to high school days. She joined the Air National Guard 14 years ago so that she could support her daughter. She's served our country in Iraq, Afghanistan, Qatar,  Korea, and in several states here in the country. 

Recently, her husband left her because he didn't that a mom should be continuing in the military.  He left her while she was deployed to Korea and far away from her three wonderful and smart girl.

Michelle has so much potential that she's in the middle of completing Officer Candidate School for the Air Force.  She graduates next month and being an officer is a sign of her leadership potential and her dedication to the country.

Michelle Needs her Daughters at her Graduation

Michelle can't afford to fly her daughters down to Alabama to watch her graduation Officer Candidate School. For Michelle, her graduation is a way to explain to her daughters why her time away from is about serving our country and being a loving and responsible mother. Michelle wants her daughters to see that through hard work and dedication the whole world is possible to them.

Any money raised above the goal will go to help Michelle and her daughters. 

Don't forget to share online- facebook and twitter.

story:
I'm Thomas Corbett I am 7 years old and I have a twin sister called Isabel and a younger brother called Daniel. 

I suffer from Cerebral Palsy. Cerebral palsy is a permanent neurological condition and affects each person differently. It is caused by damage to the brain. There is no cure.

I was born prematurely and failed to reach many of my developmental milestones unlike my twin sister Isabel who has not been affected. 

I am unable to walk. It has also affected my fine motor skills and I am unable to write and find simple tasks extremely difficult. My speech and eyesight have been affected  and also my ability to process information.

I need 24 hour help and care with all my daily living skills .  I go to the Rookeries School Carleton Pontefract and I have a full time teaching assistant to look after me.

I am hoping this page will raise awareness of my condition and help raise money for the expensive equipment and treatment I need for my long road ahead.

If you can help in anyway, however small I would be so grateful.

Thanks!

story:
ActivMotion Bar in the Press

 

How Do You Use an ActivMotion Bar?

1) Attempting to keep your bar level and the ball bearings stable and centered during your exercise. This is easier said than done because the ball bearings will always be rolling, challenging your balance, body awareness, and core stability!

 

 

2) Purposely tipping, tilting, and swinging the bar from side to side as the internal ball  bearings shift and generate momentum that results in tremendous core activation when they  “hit” the end of the bar!

 

 
 

All of the video content available on our FREE APP and online will clearly guide you through usage in a simple, safe, fun, and challenging way!

The Anatomy of an ActivMotion Bar

ActivMotion Bars are hollow and partially filled with ball bearings that shift dynamically within. The graphics below highlight the major components of our products. You will notice that every AMB starts with a rigid steel tube that is powder coated with a textured gray finish for easy handling. The gray tube is then printed with graphics that indicate hand placement, bar weight, and product branding.

Each steel tube then has a PVC tube inserted telescopically inside of it. Within this PVC tube, the steel ball bearings are housed. Each end of the bar is plugged with a soft piece of rubber that insulates noise and cushions the ball bearings when they roll from end to end.

Finally, at each end of the bar, a steel rivet seals each end, ensuring the ball bearings can never come out. A colored end cap is tightly press-fitted over each end for a nice aesthetic finish.

ActivMotion Bars come in six weights: 4.5, 6, 8, 10, 15 and 18-pounds. The lightest three options (by far the most popular) are being made available during the campaign (initially).

Think of the available 4.5, 6, and 8-pound perks as the beginner, intermediate, and advanced options. We know that this amount of resistance doesn’t sound like a lot...but just wait! When the resistance is shifting, your body works nearly twice as hard to stabilize itself (see the science section below).

 

​

 

 

 

 

Timeline

 

 
 

Our Mission to Make the World More Balanced 

We are embarking on this entrepreneurial mission to bring ActivMotion Bar to the masses to help as many people as possible IGNITE™ their fitness and IGNITE™ their lives. Taking the best from our fitness professional education that has brought success to thousands of trainers and gym members all over the world, we are now inspired to create a full 60-day home training program that brings the same fun, innovation, excitement, and results to people in their homes.

The program will be comprised of simple, progressive 20-minute daily workouts that are delivered by great instructors. The workouts will be modifiable for almost anyone’s fitness level and will fit into almost anyone’s schedule. And these routines will be designed to ensure that every 20 minutes is spent maximizing core muscle engagement and caloric expenditure with the ActivMotion Bar!

To create this program and effectively advertise it, we will need to achieve our fundraising goal of $50,000. Here is how the money will be spent:

 

 

The Science Behind the ActivMotion Bar Advantage

ActivMotion Bars are filled with rolling steel ball bearings that shift gently during movements, producing an unstable and challenging stimulus that promotes enhanced core and total body strength, increased balance, and improved flexibility. People can significantly improve their fitness levels and mind-body awareness as they feel and hear the rolling weights during every exercise!

According to an independent study conducted at the University of Michigan in 2015, ActivMotion Bars activate muscles of the core and extremities up to 173% more than standard weighted fitness tools.

This means that with every minute you spend training with an ActivMotion Bar, you can expect a dramatic increase in calorie burn and the activation and strengthening of the most important muscles in your body: your core!

Here are our shirt options! Join the AMB team with one of these awesome dry fit workout tees!

 

A very limited supply of colored AMBs is now available!!

 

Your At-Home Tools

Our simple and user-friendly app can be downloaded for free on any Apple or Android device. Just search for “ActivMotion Bar App” and immediately have access to workouts, exercise tutorials, and other great content! We also currently have a limited number of DVD workouts that were filmed when we launched in 2014.

 

 

 

 

5-Minute Holiday Plank Challenge

 

 

Shipping Now!

 

 

 

$1 Resistance Bands Perk

 

Frequently Asked Questions

Q: How do I know which ActivMotion Bar is right for me?

A: Don’t stress about choosing the right ActivMotion Bars – every weight will give you a great workout! When making your decision, take into account your fitness level, age, and goals. If you’re a beginner, new to exercise, or are over the age of 50, try to start with the 4.5-pound. The 6-pound ActivMotion Bar is popular with those who are reasonably fit. Get the 8-pound bar if you are advanced. While every bar will give you a fantastic total body workout, many folks choose to purchase one of our multi-bar bundles in order to expand the variety and intensity of their workouts or to challenge themselves to progress to higher levels of fitness.

Q: If I order more than one bar, how do I tell you which ones to ship me?

A: We will email you promptly to ask which bars you would like. Don't worry....we have you covered.

Q: When will I receive my perk?

A: If you purchased hard goods like ActivMotion Bars, DVDs, shirts, etc., your order is guaranteed to arrive within two weeks of purchasing!

Q: When will the IGNITE 60-day home program be available?

A: If all goes as planned, IGNITE™ will be available on March 1, 2017.

Q: Is there a warranty?

A: All ActivMotion Bar (AMB) products are created with the finest craftsmanship and superb quality control. We are confident that our products will surpass your expectations of both quality and functionality. AMB products are warranted to be free from manufacturing defects for 90 days from the date of sale. This does not include normal wear, such as minor abrasions.

Q: Do you ship to locations outside of the continental U.S.?

A: Because of the high shipping costs associated with shipping individual orders internationally, we are limiting sales to the continental U.S. If you are outside of this region and wish to contribute, please contact us and we will do our best to connect you with one of our distribution partners closest to your region.

Q: Will the ball bearings come out or are they changeable?

A: No. Each AMB is permanently sealed at each end. The ball bearings cannot be removed for any purpose.

Q: Where can I get some workout content to start using my AMB right away until IGNITE™ is here?

A: You can download our free app, search YouTube, or purchase one of the DVDs that are available. Also, check out this blog post for a great starter's guide!

Q: I placed my order between the campaign dates of 11/12/16 and 1/11/17. Do I get a copy of IGNITE?

A: Yes!!! You will receive a free digital copy of IGNITE when it becomes available in March.

Q: If I order after 1/11/17, can I still get IGNITE at no charge?

A: Unfortunately, you had to contribute to the campaign between our "live" dates of 11/12/16 and 1/11/17 to get IGNITE for free. If you order after 1/11/17, you can still get IGNITE at the pre-sale discounted cost of $39.99. This is still over half off of what it will retail for beginning in March.

story:
The Hipee is a user friendly, sturdy, lightweight, portable exercise tool that challenges your balance and stability and concentrates your effort due to less surface area on which to sit.  Therefore, you get more overall benefit because your entire body needs to be engaged to maintain balance and stability.  You will discover more focused benefits with the Hipee because the body part(s) that are target become highlighted. 

 

 

The Hipee provides comfort and support that allows you to exercise more comfortably when doing floor exercises. If you have suffered from tailbone discomfort when performing sitting exercises on the floor, the Hipee will quickly become one of your new favorite pieces of exercise equipment.  

You can also use the Hipee as a comfortable cushion for just sitting on the floor and can travel easily with you. It is also a great cushion for the bathtub.

With the help of our supporters, the Hipee will become a new tool for people to use on the floor, at the gym, training centers, yoga studios, at home or inside the bathtub.

What We Need & What You Get

With your help, we hope to create a "Hipee Culture" where people can experience a new way to use the floor or the bathtub. It is amazing to see people's faces when they sit on the Hipee for the first time and try to do very basic moves that some can't do because they can't handle the pressure of the hard floor. The Hipee is seeking to get out to the world with the Indiegogo Campaign and get to the hands of new consumers. Please help the Hipee reach its full potential and get to the hands of many new Hipee users to put an end to the "Floor Pain Era".

The Hipee is made in the USA-Patent Pending and units are ready to be shipped.

Hipee Indiegogo backers get a very attractive discount from the original retail price and will be some of the very first users of the product! 

Thank you for your support to the Hipee! Please help us to spread the Hipee with the world by following us on social media and sharing our campaign in your own circle. We believe that anyone can benefit from the multiple uses of the Hipee and look forward to getting it into the hands of more people to continue the growth of the multiple ways to use it.

 

@hipeefitness  

www.hipeefitness.com
